> **tldr:** The Fed's 2% inflation target adds roughly a 30% head start to the market's average annual gain of about 6.7%.

The Federal Reserve aims for 2% inflation. We'll call this drift. How does it stack against historical S&P 500 performance since 2000?

```{python}
#| label: sp500-data
#| fig-cap: "S&P 500 performance since 2000"
#| fig-alt: "Line chart with red dots marking down years"
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

returns = np.array([
    -0.1014, -0.1304, -0.2337, 0.2638, 0.0899, 0.03, 0.1362,
    0.0353, -0.3849, 0.2345, 0.1278, 0.0, 0.1341, 0.296,
    0.1139, -0.0073, 0.0954, 0.1942, -0.0624, 0.2888,
    0.1626, 0.2689, -0.1811, 0.24
])

years = np.arange(2000, 2000 + len(returns))
prices = 100 * np.cumprod(1 + returns)

plt.plot(years, prices, label="S&P 500")
for y, r, p in zip(years, returns, prices):
    if r < 0:
        plt.scatter(y, p, color="red")
plt.xlabel("Year")
plt.ylabel("Index level (normalized)")
plt.title("S&P 500 since 2000")
plt.tight_layout()
```

```{python}
# count down years and calculate averages
import pandas as pd

series = pd.Series(returns, index=years)
down_years = (series < 0).sum()
percent_down = 100 * down_years / len(series)
avg_return = series.mean()
head_start = 100 * 0.02 / avg_return
print(f"Down years: {down_years} of {len(series)} ({percent_down:.1f}% of the time)")
print(f"Average annual return: {avg_return:.3%}")
print(f"2% drift is a {head_start:.1f}% head start on annual gains")
```
